intro: Galium pogonanthum var. trichopetalum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, hairy stems and small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine pubescence. The plant produces clusters of tiny white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream sides. Its growth habit is herbaceous, with the ability to spread via rhizomes, making it a common groundcover in suitable habitats.
